thread.title_full: Joe Greene 'Very, Very Disappointed' in Antonio Brown over Facebook Incident

author: Tyler Conway
title: Joe Greene 'Very, Very Disappointed' in Antonio Brown over Facebook Incident
text:
Joe Greene 'Very, Very Disappointed' in Antonio Brown over Facebook Incident Keith Srakocic/Associated Press Tyler Conway Featured Columnist March 24, 2017 Former Pittsburgh Steelers defensive lineman Joe Greene said he was "very, very disappointed" in wideout Antonio Brown over the Facebook Live video he posted from the locker room following the team's playoff win over the Kansas City Chiefs . "Those types of things can't be tolerated," Greene said on 93.7 The Fan, per Jeremy Fowler of ESPN.com. "My first thought was, I would have to say goodbye [to Brown], but that's me." Greene played for the Steelers from 1969 to 1981. He was a four-time Super Bowl champion and earned 10 Pro Bowl berths, helping turn Pittsburgh into one of the premier organizations in football. He said: 
When you sign on with the Steelers, you're signing on with an organization that you gotta put your job, as [former coach] Chuck [Noll] always told us, there was God, family and football. And when you start to put yourself above all of that, then the selfishness comes into place, then you get individual acts like the ones then that I personally think is a detriment to the entire organization and what we're trying to do in Pittsburgh. ... That's a youthful mistake, but in my view, I just don't think that it should be tolerated. 
Brown, the Steelers' leading receiver and arguably their best player, went on Facebook Live following the win over Kansas City. His recording, which was mostly filled with boisterous celebrations from himself and teammates, also included coach Mike Tomlin 's postgame speech to the team. 
Tomlin later admonished Brown for the fiasco, who publicly apologized for the distraction. The Steelers lost their following game, an AFC championship clash with the New England Patriots . 
Steelers owner Art Rooney said Brown's antics were "little annoyances, with the emphasis on little" in January. The team signed him to a new five-year contract this offseason. Like the new article format? !
